skill.name: container-hadolint
skill.description: Dockerfile security linting and best practice validation using Hadolint with 100+ built-in rules aligned to CIS Docker Benchmark. Use when: (1) Analyzing Dockerfiles for security misconfigurations and anti-patterns, (2) Enforcing container image security best practices in CI/CD pipelines, (3) Detecting hardcoded secrets and credentials in container builds, (4) Validating compliance with CIS Docker Benchmark requirements, (5) Integrating shift-left container security into developer workflows, (6) Providing remediation guidance for insecure Dockerfile instructions.

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation and configuration skill with no executable code. The skill provides guidance for using Hadolint, an open-source Dockerfile linter, along with CI/CD templates and configuration files for container security validation. No scripts, network calls, or file system access beyond reading user-provided Dockerfiles. All behavior matches the stated purpose of Dockerfile security linting.

content.value_statement: Container images often contain security misconfigurations that create deployment risks. This skill integrates Hadolint to automatically validate Dockerfiles against CIS Docker Benchmark requirements, detecting issues like unpinned packages, root user usage, and hardcoded secrets before images are built.
actual_capabilities: Scan Dockerfiles for security misconfigurations using Hadolint
Validate against CIS Docker Benchmark requirements
Generate JSON, SARIF, and Code Quality reports for CI/CD integration
Configure rule severity and trusted registries for organizational standards
Detect hardcoded secrets and credentials in container builds
Provide remediation guidance for insecure Dockerfile instructions
limitations: Only validates Dockerfile syntax and best practices, not runtime container security
Does not scan base image vulnerabilities (use Trivy or Grype for that)
Requires Hadolint to be installed on the system
Does not automatically fix issues, only detects and reports them

output_examples.input: Scan my Dockerfile with hadolint and explain the findings
output: DL3002 Error: Never switch back to root - Create a dedicated non-root user and switch to it early in the Dockerfile
DL3008 Warning: Pin versions in apt-get install - Add specific version numbers to prevent supply chain attacks
DL3020 Error: Use COPY instead of ADD - ADD can fetch from URLs and auto-extract archives, creating security risks
DL3025 Warning: Use JSON notation for CMD/ENTRYPOINT - Shell form enables injection attacks

best_practices: Run hadolint in CI/CD pipelines before building container images to catch issues early
Use strict configuration for production images and permissive for legacy Dockerfile migration
Combine hadolint with image scanners like Trivy or Grype for comprehensive container security
anti_patterns: Ignoring hadolint warnings without documenting the risk acceptance decision
Using :latest tags for base images instead of pinned versions with digests
Putting credentials in ENV or ARG instructions where they persist in image layers

faq.question: What is the difference between hadolint and container image scanners?
faq.answer: Hadolint validates Dockerfile syntax and best practices before building. Image scanners like Trivy scan the built image for vulnerabilities. Use both for complete coverage.

faq.question: Does hadolint detect all security issues in Dockerfiles?
faq.answer: Hadolint catches Dockerfile-specific issues. It does not detect base image CVEs, runtime misconfigurations, or network policies. Combine with other security tools.

faq.question: How do I integrate hadolint into my existing CI/CD pipeline?
faq.answer: Use the provided GitHub Actions or GitLab CI templates. Hadolint supports JSON, SARIF, and Code Quality formats for integration with most CI systems.

faq.question: Is my Dockerfile data safe when using hadolint?
faq.answer: Hadolint only reads Dockerfiles locally. Reports stay on your infrastructure unless you explicitly configure CI/CD to share them. Review report configurations before publishing.

faq.question: Why does hadolint flag my Dockerfile when it builds fine?
faq.answer: Hadolint checks for security best practices and potential issues, not syntax errors. A Dockerfile can build successfully while still containing security anti-patterns.

faq.question: Can I ignore specific hadolint rules for my use case?
faq.answer: Yes, use .hadolint.yaml configuration to ignore rules. Document why each ignored rule is acceptable for your security context and compliance requirements.
